entry.title: Poor-man's Reverberation Modelling with MATLAB®
entry.content:
Here we create an artificial simple reverberation using a convolution. This is an example of a LTI system and we select the input to be any audio signal (reverb-in.wav) and the output will be the audio signal with reverberation/echo (reverb-out.wav) .

Page Index

  • Reverberation is Convolution
  • MATLAB® Function — reverb.m
  • Output Plot — reverb.png
  • Downloads

Reverberation is Convolution

Input sound is and output sound is the convolution

where models the reverberation (echo) system.

Here we choose

so becomes the sum of two (non-zero) terms

The input sound files have a sample rate of 11,025 Hz, which means 3,000 samples is about 0.27 seconds. So the reverberation has a direct path of magnitude 0.6 and an echo path of magnitude 0.4 with delay of 0.27 seconds.

MATLAB® Function — reverb.m

Output Plot — reverb.png

Downloads

  • reverb.m
  • reverb.png
  • reverb-in.wav
  • reverb-out.wav
  • reverb-out8.wav

entry.title: Derivative of CT signals with MATLAB®
entry.content:
We use fine-scale discrete time to emulate continuous time. Then we use discrete approximation to the derivative to model a system whose output is the derivative of the input.

Page Index

  • MATLAB® Modelling of a Derivative System
    • MATLAB® Function — deriv.m
    • MATLAB® Function — ddemo.m
    • Output png figure — ddemo.png
  • Downloads

MATLAB® Modelling of a Derivative System

MATLAB® Function — deriv.m

Create an arbitray function ; then we want to determine/plot (numerically)

over some time range.

As an example, take

on the interval , with fine-scale time divsion of . Plot and .

MATLAB® Function — ddemo.m

Output png figure — ddemo.png

When plotting we overlaid dots on the continuous curves to indicate where the sample values are (spaced at 0.05).

Downloads

  • deriv.m
  • ddemo.m
  • ddemo.png

entry.title: Hacking with MATLAB® and Complex Exponentials
entry.content:
In the lectures it was illustrated how to use MATLAB® to explore complex exponentials. Complex values and are the same symbols as shown on Slide 68 of the lectures.

Page Index

  • 1) CT Complex Exponential
    • MATLAB® code for CT Complex Exponential — ctcexp.m
  • 2) DT Complex Exponential
    • MATLAB® code for DT Complex Exponential — dtcexp.m
  • 3) Revised and Improved MATLAB® code — cmplxexp.m
    • Output png Figure — ct-cmplxexp.png
    • Output png Figure — dt-cmplxexp.png
  • 4) Downloads

1) CT Complex Exponential

The complex exponential is given by

This is computed (using the MATLAB® script shown below) and plotted (in the figure). The explicit values here are and .

MATLAB® code for CT Complex Exponential — ctcexp.m

2) DT Complex Exponential

For discrete time it is very similiar.

The samples are now at integer values and we plot the complex exponential as a sequence of stars. An underlying “continuous” complex exponential is plotted in green to clarify how the discrete time samples are distributed.

MATLAB® code for DT Complex Exponential — dtcexp.m

3) Revised and Improved MATLAB® code — cmplxexp.m

This code merges the plots and illustrates some other tricks with MATLAB®

Output png Figure — ct-cmplxexp.png

Output png Figure — dt-cmplxexp.png

entry.title: Get Started with this Site
entry.content:
The official course description is available on Programs and Courses linked here: ENGN2228 Signal Processing. This course as part of the Electronics and Communication Systems Major but it can also be done as an elective.

Site navigation is through the slideout menu on the left. Start exploring.
